channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Scientists Move To Establish Wildlife Preserve At Guantanamo Bay
item.description: August 15, 2017 - In the 15 years since the Guantanamo Bay detention camp was established to house suspected terrorists, a green buffer surrounding the facility to keep out the world has reverted back to the wild. Now some scientists would like to turn it into a protected research area.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 15, 2017 - In the 15 years since the Guantanamo Bay detention camp was established to house suspected terrorists, a green buffer surrounding the facility to keep out the world has reverted back to the wild. Now some scientists would like to turn it into a protected research area. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/15/543730262/scientists-move-to-establish-wildlife-preserve-at-guantanamo-bay

item.title: Can We Feed The World With Farmed Fish?
item.description: August 15, 2017 - New research suggests there is space on the open ocean to farm essentially all the seafood humans can eat — and then some. But such volumes of fish and shellfish could not be grown without costs.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 15, 2017 - New research suggests there is space on the open ocean to farm essentially all the seafood humans can eat — and then some. But such volumes of fish and shellfish could not be grown without costs. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/15/543675398/can-we-feed-the-world-with-farmed-fish

item.title: In The Event Of A Nuclear Blast, Don't Condition Your Hair
item.description: August 15, 2017 - That advice came in guidelines issued to residents of Guam on how to prepare for a missile threat on the island. The reason is conditioner can trap radioactive particles in strands of hair.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 15, 2017 - That advice came in guidelines issued to residents of Guam on how to prepare for a missile threat on the island. The reason is conditioner can trap radioactive particles in strands of hair. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/15/543647878/in-the-event-of-a-nuclear-blast-don-t-condition-your-hair

item.title: Science, Solitude And The Sacred On The Appalachian Trail
item.description: August 15, 2017 - There is no greater source for science, for the inspiration to do science, than the wild; that is where the sense of sacredness at the root of science's aspiration lives, says blogger Adam Frank.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 15, 2017 - There is no greater source for science, for the inspiration to do science, than the wild; that is where the sense of sacredness at the root of science's aspiration lives, says blogger Adam Frank. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/15/543667558/science-solitude-and-the-sacred-on-the-appalachian-trail

item.title: Greenland Is Still Burning, But The Smoke May Be The Real Problem
item.description: August 15, 2017 - Wildfires are still burning in western Greenland, close to the Arctic island's ice sheet. As the fires burn, they release black particles that can coat the ice and snow, and make it melt more quickly.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 15, 2017 - Wildfires are still burning in western Greenland, close to the Arctic island's ice sheet. As the fires burn, they release black particles that can coat the ice and snow, and make it melt more quickly. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/15/543406558/greenland-is-still-burning-but-the-smoke-may-be-the-real-problem

item.title: 6,000-Year-Old Knee Joints Suggest Osteoarthritis Isn't Just Wear And Tear
item.description: August 15, 2017 - Even after a Harvard team took into account differences in age and weight among ancient specimens and knees today, they found that modern humans tend to have more osteoarthritis.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 15, 2017 - Even after a Harvard team took into account differences in age and weight among ancient specimens and knees today, they found that modern humans tend to have more osteoarthritis. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/15/543402095/creaky-knees

item.title: New Study Highlights Strong Link Between Basic Research And Inventions
item.description: August 14, 2017 - A big waste of money or the engine of marketplace innovation? That's how some people see basic scientific research. Now a new study shows how basic research and inventions are connected.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 14, 2017 - A big waste of money or the engine of marketplace innovation? That's how some people see basic scientific research. Now a new study shows how basic research and inventions are connected. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/14/543477432/new-study-highlights-strong-link-between-basic-research-and-inventions

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Key Step To Rolling Back Auto Fuel Standards
item.description: August 14, 2017 - The Trump administration has opened a 45-day comment period ahead of proposed changes to Obama-era EPA rules for greenhouse gas emissions for cars and light trucks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 14, 2017 - The Trump administration has opened a 45-day comment period ahead of proposed changes to Obama-era EPA rules for greenhouse gas emissions for cars and light trucks. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/14/543474251/trump-administration-takes-key-step-to-rolling-back-auto-fuel-standards

item.title: In Children's Storybooks, Realism Has Advantages
item.description: August 14, 2017 - Young children have an easier time exporting what they learn from a fictional storybook to the real world when the storybook is realistic, says psychologist Tania Lombrozo.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 14, 2017 - Young children have an easier time exporting what they learn from a fictional storybook to the real world when the storybook is realistic, says psychologist Tania Lombrozo. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/14/543405845/in-children-s-storybooks-realism-has-advantages

item.title: Why Future Earthlings Won't See Total Solar Eclipses
item.description: August 14, 2017 - The Earth won't enjoy total solar eclipses forever because the moon is moving farther away, so it looks smaller and smaller over time.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 14, 2017 - The Earth won't enjoy total solar eclipses forever because the moon is moving farther away, so it looks smaller and smaller over time. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/14/542700588/why-future-earthlings-wont-see-total-solar-eclipses

item.title: The Call-In: The Solar Eclipse
item.description:
August 13, 2017 - This week, on The Call-In, we answer all your questions about the upcoming solar eclipse — how to protect your eyes, and what to do if the day is cloudy.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/08/13/543197278/the-call-in-the-solar-eclipse
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 13, 2017 - This week, on The Call-In, we answer all your questions about the upcoming solar eclipse — how to protect your eyes, and what to do if the day is cloudy. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/13/543197278/the-call-in-the-solar-eclipse

item.title: People In Nepal Used To Think Vultures Were Bad Luck. Not Anymore
item.description: August 13, 2017 - The number of vultures in South Asia has plummeted. But "restaurants" to feed rescued chicks and wild vultures are good for the birds — and for the local economy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 13, 2017 - The number of vultures in South Asia has plummeted. But "restaurants" to feed rescued chicks and wild vultures are good for the birds — and for the local economy. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/08/13/541138366/people-in-nepal-used-to-think-vultures-were-bad-luck-not-anymore

item.title: Researchers: Hackers Could Encode Human DNA With Malicious Software
item.description: August 12, 2017 - University of Washington researchers say malware could be encoded into DNA strands. NPR's Scott Simon speaks to researcher Karl Koscher about the findings and what they mean for gene sequencing.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 12, 2017 - University of Washington researchers say malware could be encoded into DNA strands. NPR's Scott Simon speaks to researcher Karl Koscher about the findings and what they mean for gene sequencing. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/12/542998566/researchers-hackers-could-encode-human-dna-with-malicious-software

item.title: 40 Years Ago, NASA Launched Message To Aliens Into Deep Space
item.description: August 11, 2017 - Forty years ago, NASA launched two Voyager spacecraft into deep space. Onboard both were gold discs with music, greetings and sounds from Earth — a message to aliens. Ann Druyan, the creative director of the project, talks about how they decided what message to put in the interstellar bottle.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 11, 2017 - Forty years ago, NASA launched two Voyager spacecraft into deep space. Ann Druyan, the creative director of the project, talks about how they decided what message to put in the interstellar bottle. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/11/542867050/40-years-ago-nasa-launched-message-to-aliens-into-deep-space

item.title: Success In Placing Shelter Dogs Takes More Than Temperament Tests
item.description: August 11, 2017 - Blogger Alva Noë talks with a dog trainer who says the need to give shelters, handlers and adopters the resources required to keep dogs and people supported and safe is critical in the process.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
